title: Recommended handling of I/O for pyfunc?
body:
I'm developing a pytorch model that take multi-dimensional data (Currently 3D data, 4D if considering batch processing)

Currently, I have two options for exporting models logged using the `mlflow.pytorch` package:
A) Export pytorch model directly via `mlflow.pytorch.load_model`

This requires me to duplicate code for preprocessing. For now I can embed this into my model class and handle preprocessing through my own code. 

In my case, this means adding a new `predict` function to my model class, which accepts a URL parameter, reads the file, converts the file to features (3D numpy data), packs this into a Tensor, and finally calls the native `forward` method of pytorch.

B) Export function via `mlflow.pyfunc.load_pyfunc`

This function seems to be unusable for my use-case. The model requires a dataframe as input, but I cannot easily embed a 3D or 4D tensor as a dataframe. Alternatively, it may be advantageous to use URLs as inputs, and embed pre-processing logic as indicated above. However, I cannot find a recommended way of handling this type of issue.


I have a suitable work-around using native pytorch, but it seems pyfunc integration is not adaptable for this use-case. 

Are there any recommended methods to overcome this type of issue? Do you have any plans to further streamline model packaging with easily configurable pre-processing steps?
